ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Very few East Asian media scholars besides Prof. Gerow could craft such an in-depth, thought-provoking course on theories of TV in Japan. 10/10.
This course was a wonderful primer on Japanese television and the tools with which it should be analyzed.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: At times, there are too many readings to cover meaningfully in a single class session. Because the screenings are so well curated, more effort could be made to incorporate TV content into class discussion.
It would be nice to see even more than we did; time constraints are the biggest concern for the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: One of Prof. Gerow's most challenging courses, but rewarding through-and-through. A wide-ranging introduction to Japanese television, with a focus on early theorizations of TV and Japanese popular culture. Highly recommended.
Only if they speak Japanese well and want to put in the work!
